conclusion: To compare average velocities, analyze velocity-time graphs; average velocity is total displacement divided by total time.
The area under the velocity-time graph represents the displacement of the car.
For Car A, the area under the curve from t=0 to t=t1 is the region bounded by the curve and the time axis.
For Car B, the area under the curve from t=0 to t=t1 is the region bounded by the curve and the time axis.
The area under the curve for Car A is larger than for Car B, indicating greater displacement for Car A.
Average velocity is given by total displacement divided by total time.
Since the time interval is the same for both cars, the car with the larger displacement has the larger average velocity.
Car A has a larger area under its velocity-time graph, indicating a larger displacement.
Car A has a greater average velocity than Car B over the time interval from t=0 to t=t1.
